name: Statistical Graphics and Visualization

prereqs.text: (36-202 [] at least D) or (36-208 [] at least D) or (36-219 [] at least D) or (21-325 [] at least D) or (36-235 [] at least D) or (36-309 [] at least D) or (36-225 [] at least D) or (36-218 [] at least D) or (70-208 [] at least D) or (15-259 [] at least D)

long_desc: Graphical displays of quantitative information take on many forms, and they help us understand data and statistical methods by hopefully clearly communicating arguments, results, and ideas. This course introduces students to the most common forms of graphical displays and their uses and misuses. Ideally, graphs are designed according to three key elements The data structure, the graphs audience, and the designers intended message. Students will learn how to create welldesigned graphs and understand them from a statistical perspective. Furthermore, the course will consider complex data structures that are becoming increasingly common in data visualizations temporal, spatial, and text data we will discuss common ways to process these data that make them easy to visualize. As time permits, we may also consider more advanced graphical methods e.g., interactive graphics and computergenerated animations. In addition to two weekly lectures, there will be weekly computer labs and homework assignments where students use R to visualize and analyze real datasets. Along the way, students also make monthly Piazza posts discussing the strengths and weaknesses of a graph they found online, thereby critiquing real graphical designs found in the wild. The course culminates in a group final project, where students make publicfacing data visualizations and analyses for a real dataset. All assignments will be in R although this is not a programming class, using programmingbased statistical software like R is essential to create modernday graphics, and this class will give you practice using this kind of software. Throughout, communication skills usually written or visual, but sometimes spoken will play an important role. Indeed, if its true that a picture speaks a thousand words, then ideally the one thousand words you are communicating with your graphics are statistically correct, clear, and compelling.

custom_fields.goals: Students will master the fundamentals of reproducible data analysis, from pinpointing the graphs and analyses that are most appropriate for a given dataset to writing easily readable and reproducible code. Furthermore, students will design graphs to explore data, test hypotheses, form research questions, and communicate accurate and honest arguments, such that their graphs are easily understandable for technical and nontechnical audiences. Along the way, students will learn how to argue why certain design choices were made for a graph, and describe graphs concisely and accurately to technical and nontechnical audiences in writing and orally. Finally, students will assess and critique statistical graphics in popular media this includes describing the strengths and weaknesses of a given graphical design, as well as communicating how a graphical design can be improved.
custom_fields.key_topics: Exploratory data analysis; variable types and data structures; visualization and inference for categorical and quantitative data; visualizing statistical uncertainty (e.g., confidence intervals and sampling distributions); visualization and inference for regression and clustering; dimension reduction with principal component analysis and t-SNE; complex data structures like text, maps, and time series; interactive graphics.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Some basic familiarity with statistical inference (e.g., p-values and confidence intervals), variable types (e.g., categorical versus quantitative variables), and basic data structures (i.e., matrices). Though not required, some familiarity with R is preferred.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Weekly homeworks and lab assignments, monthly piazza posts, a lab exam, and a final group project (as a public-facing digital file, poster presentation and written report).

Students will learn how to create graphs such that they address the three key elements of graphical design: The data structure, the graph's audience, and the designer's intended message. Furthermore, students will gain a better understanding of how appropriate statistical analyses can complement their graphs. Students will also gain a greater appreciation/understanding for statistical methods (like linear regression) by learning how to visualize these methods and their underlying statistical uncertainty. Finally, students will learn how to work with complex data structures such as high-dimensional data, text, maps, and time series.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Lecture slides, hands-on computer labs, online tutorials, case studies of real data analyses.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Usually none, but there is a final project (due at the end of the semester), and teams of students will have 1-2 check-in meetings with the instructor as they prepare that project.
